channel.title: Listen to the land
channel.description:
America's literary heritage is explored through readings of short stories, poems, folklore, journalism and legends. A profile of a nation in terms of its living language. By sharing aloud the writings of the United States, past and present, a fuller appreciation of what it means to be American can be found. The series is narrated by Richard S. Burdick.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: The fertile Twenties, part 2
item.description: This program, the second of two parts, focuses on the exceptional American writings of the 1920s.
item.dc:creator: Keeler, James
item.dc:subject: American culture

item.title: As others see us
item.description: In this program, Burdick reads various writings from foreign visitors to the United States, relating their observations about American people and culture.
item.dc:creator: Keeler, James
item.dc:subject: Europeans

item.title: Nuggets from the gold rush
item.description: This episode discusses various stories that emerged from the California gold rush of the mid-nineteenth century.
item.dc:creator: Keeler, James
item.dc:subject: Fiction--19th century.

item.title: All about animals, part 1
item.description: This program, the first of two parts, explores American writings on domesticated animals.

item.dc:subject: American culture

item.title: Barracks, battlefields, & birthrights, part 2
item.description: This program, the second of two parts, focuses on American literature related to war, particularly World War I and World War II.
item.dc:creator: Keeler, James
item.dc:subject: War.
